samples.context: Tissue is defined as a group of cells that are similar in structure and/or work together to achieve a particular function. The three main types of simple tissues in plants are: (i) Parenchyma (ii) Collenchyma (iii) Sclerenchyma.
samples.question: What are the three types of simple plant tissues?

samples.context: Complex tissues in plants are made up of more than one type of cells, while simple tissues consist of only one type.
samples.question: What distinguishes complex tissues from simple tissues?

samples.context: The following four types of elements make up xylem tissue: (i) Xylem tracheids (tubular unicellular), (ii) Xylem vessels (multicellular), (iii) Xylem parenchyma (stores food and helps in sideways conduction of water), (iv) Xylem fibres (provide mechanical support).
samples.question: What types of elements compose xylem tissue?

samples.context: The constituents of phloem tissue are: (i) Sieve tubes (tubular living cells with perforated end walls) (ii) Companion cell (living cells) (iii) Phloem parenchyma (living cells) (iv) Phloem fibres (non-living and sclerenchyma cells).
samples.question: What makes up phloem tissue?

samples.context: Complex Plant Tissues include xylem, which consists of four types of elements that serve different functions in transportation and support.
samples.question: What is the main function of xylem tissue?

samples.context: Complex tissues in plants include xylem and phloem, both of which consist of various cell types contributing to their function.
samples.question: What are the two main types of complex tissues in plants?
